elements.title: Acquisitions of Solar Developers and Gas-Fired Power Station

data.value: RWE acquired Poland-based Alpha Solar, adding an approximately 3 GW solar project pipeline. The total purchase price was €123 million and the acquisition included a team of around 60 employees.

In early March 2023, RWE acquired JBM Solar, a UK developer with a mature 6.1 GW development pipeline (3.8 GW solar and 2.3 GW battery storage), along with a team of 30 experts. Initial assets are scheduled for commissioning by the end of 2024, with an expected build rate of about 450 MW per year thereafter.

data.key: Acquisition of Magnum Gas-Fired Power Station (Netherlands)
data.value: RWE acquired the Magnum gas-fired power plant from Vattenfall. With a net capacity of 1.4 GW and a preliminary purchase price of €443 million, the transaction also included a neighbouring 5.6 MW solar farm. The plant, operational since 2013, has options for hydrogen conversion.

elements.title: Annual Report Insights

data.key: Year over Year Increase in Renewable Generation
data.value: Renewable electricity production rose by 11 % to 35,499 GWh.
Wind power generation increased by 20 % compared to the previous year.

data.key: Stake Increase in Rampion Offshore Wind Farm
data.value: Stake in the Rampion offshore wind farm increased from 30.1 % to 50.1 % as of April 1, 2021.
Solar power volumes showed strong growth due to new assets.
Installed capacity rose to 39.3 GW as of December 31, 2022.
Generation capacity grew by 2.3 GW compared to 2021.
Successfully completed wind farms including Triton Knoll (857 MW), Kaskasi (342 MW), among others.
Decommissioned Unit A (294 MW) of Neurath lignite-fired power station.
Electricity purchases from external suppliers totaled 43,168 GWh in 2022.

elements.title: Change of Control Effects on Financing Instruments and Executive Compensation

data.value: Disclosure relating to German takeover law and the effects of a change of control on financing instruments.

€8 billion syndicated credit lines include clauses that suspend drawings in the event of a change of control. Lenders have 30 days from notification to negotiate a continuation; failure allows revocation or cancellation of the loan.

RWE bonds issued publicly in 2021 and 2022 contain change-of-control clauses allowing investors to request redemption if RWE’s long-term credit rating falls below investment grade or rating agencies cease issuing ratings.

Two subordinated hybrid bonds (valued at €282 million and US$317 million) can be redeemed in the event of a change of control. If not redeemed and credit ratings deteriorate, their annual yield increases by 500 basis points.

Compensation agreements for the Executive Board and employees do not include additional benefits or severance rights in the event of a change of control. Performance shares are paid out or re-planned based on achievement levels at the time of the change.

The provisions align with the German Corporate Governance Code, which recommends that no special termination or severance clauses be included in Executive Board employment contracts upon a change of control.

elements.title: Taxonomy-eligible Activities Analysis - OpEx KPI Denominator

data.value: This table presents the analysis of taxonomy-eligible but not taxonomy-aligned activities in relation to OpEx KPI denominator. The data is broken down by different sections of Delegated Regulation 2021/2139. The majority of activities (67%) fall under Section 4.29, accounting for €151 million, followed by Section 4.30 (11%, €25 million) and other activities (22%, €48 million). All reported activities are related to Climate Change Mitigation (CCM), with no activities reported for Climate Change Adaptation (CCA). The total amounts sum up to €224 million, representing 100% of taxonomy-eligible but not taxonomy-aligned activities.

elements.title: Divestitures and Deconsolidations Transactions

data.value: 75% stake in onshore wind farms (Stella, Cranell, East Raymond sold in January 2021; 75% of West Raymond sold in August 2021). Deconsolidation gain of €156 million recognized in 'other operating income' and a commodity derivative expense of €34 million recognized in 'other operating expenses'. Divested assets assigned to the Onshore Wind/Solar segment.

100% shares in Energies France (Paris, France) sold at the end of April 2021 to KELAG. Deconsolidation gain of €9 million recognized in 'other operating income'. Energies France was part of the Hydro/Biomass/Gas segment.

100% shares in Investerg (São João do Estoril, Portugal) sold at the end of September 2021 to KELAG. Deconsolidation gain of €7 million recognized in 'other operating income'. Investerg was assigned to the Onshore Wind/Solar segment. KELAG is an associate company of RWE.

Sale of the grid connection for the Rampion offshore wind farm completed on 19 November 2021 to meet competition law requirements. No disposal result was recorded. The asset was part of the Offshore Wind segment.

In December 2021, parts of the Belectric Group (including BELECTRIC GmbH, Belectric France S.à.r.l., Belectric Israel Ltd., Belectric Italia s.r.l., and Belectric Solar Ltd.) were sold to Elevion Group B.V. Deconsolidation gain of €4 million recognized in 'other operating income'. Divested companies were assigned to the Onshore Wind/Solar segment.

The document also discusses consolidation principles including treatment of subsidiaries with different fiscal years, business combinations reported using the acquisition method, and the measurement of non-controlling interests and goodwill.

elements.title: Staff Reductions Due to Lignite Phaseout

data.value: The decision to bring the lignite phaseout forward will have far-reaching consequences for many RWE employees.
Although we will need more staff in the short term to operate additional lignite power stations during the present energy crisis.
Staff reductions will accelerate towards the end of the decade.
A range of compensatory measures have been planned for those impacted, e.g. early retirement plans and a statutory adjustment allowance.
Younger employees will be offered additional training, allowing them to take on new roles within or outside the company.

elements.title: Capital Expenditure and Workforce Changes
Employee Engagement, HR Transformation and Workforce Adjustments

data.value: Thousands of jobs to be cut in a socially acceptable manner due to decommissioning activities in the Coal/Nuclear segment. Job cuts are expected to increase significantly towards the end of the decade.
HR organisation rearranged to support growth; onboarding, offboarding, and internal job change processes have been standardized groupwide.
Efforts include recruiting new staff, internal job board revamp, extensive qualification and retraining measures to facilitate internal transfers and adjustment to the new decommissioning roadmap.
RWE Group improved its engagement index from 81 in 2021 to 84 in 2022, indicating a positive trend in employee engagement.

elements.title: Share-based Payment for Executives

data.value: RWE grants stock option plans to executives and members of corporate bodies, which are accounted for as cash-settled share-based payments. At the balance-sheet date, a provision equal to the prorated fair value of the payment obligation is recognized, with subsequent changes in fair value affecting income. The fair value is determined using generally accepted valuation methodologies.

elements.title: Share-based payment for executives

data.value: Long Term Incentive Plans (LTIPs) are in place as share-based payment systems known as Strategic Performance Plans (SPPs).
Uses an internal performance target (net income of relevance to remuneration) derived from the mid-term planning.
Executives receive conditionally granted virtual shares (performance shares).
Determined based on the achievement of the adjusted net income target.
Each tranche has a four-year term before payment is possible.
Conditions were adjusted and extended for grants starting from fiscal 2021.
Incorporates carbon footprint of generation portfolio and relative total shareholder return.

elements.title: LTIP SPP 2016-2020 Performance Share Details

data.value: Details of the Long-Term Incentive Plan (LTIP) and Share Performance Plan for 2016-2020 including start dates of tranches (1 Jan 2018, 1 Jan 2019, 1 Jan 2020), vesting period of 4 years, and performance target based on 'Adjusted net income'. The plan caps performance shares at 150%.
Performance shares granted increased slightly from 883,974 in 2018 to 935,331 in 2020.

Payment amount is calculated by multiplying the final number of granted performance shares by the sum of the mathematical average share price (based on the last 30 trading days prior to vesting) and dividends paid per share. The payment is capped at 200% of the grant amount.

In the event of a change of control, fully granted but unpaid performance shares are accelerated for payout using the adjusted share price from the last 30 trading days before the change and including dividends. Conditioned granted performance shares as of the effective date lapse without consideration.

elements.title: Innovation and Offshore Renewable Projects

data.value: DemoSATH project in partnership with Saitec Offshore Technologies: a catamaran-like floating platform equipped with a 2 MW turbine was launched into the water at the port of Bilbao.
Next step involves attaching the platform to a preinstalled single-point mooring system in the Bay of Biscay, enabling position adjustments based on wind, currents, and waves.
First floating solar farm became operational in mid-2022 with 13,400 modules and a total capacity of 6.1 MW, located on a lake near the Amer power station in the Netherlands.
Participation in pilot projects such as the EU-funded EU-SCORES (testing a 3 MW offshore photovoltaic plant off Belgium) and collaboration with SolarDuck on a 0.5 MW pilot plant in the North Sea.
Involvement in hydrogen projects including the GET H2 initiative and the GET H2 Nukleus project near the Lingen power station, aimed at establishing large-scale hydrogen production.

elements.title: Investment and Growth Strategy Overview

data.value: Intention to invest approximately €50 billion in new renewable energy assets over a 10-year period (2021-2030)
After divestments, expected capital expenditure is approximately €30 billion
Acquisition of US energy company Con Edison Clean Energy Businesses to boost solar production in the USA
Increase pro-rata offshore wind capacity from 3.3 GW to 8 GW by 2030, with key projects including Sofia (1.4 GW), Dogger Bank South (3 GW) and Thor (1 GW)
Onshore wind target: from 8 GW to 12 GW by 2030; Solar initial capacity of 0.8 GW with an original target of 8 GW, expected to exceed due to acquisition
Target to achieve 3 GW of installed battery storage capacity by 2030, up from 274 MW at the end of 2022, with projects including Hickory Park (40 MW battery) and others in Germany
Plan to revise strategy and update growth targets at the next Capital Market Day in Q4 2023

elements.title: Investments in Flexible Gas-Fired Power Stations and Hydrogen Strategy

data.value: Plan to build gas-fired power stations with a total capacity of 3 GW in Germany.
Primary potential sites in North Rhine-Westphalia, previously used for coal-fired generation.
Investments will be made only if necessary incentives such as investment subsidies are provided by Germany. Long-term operation using green hydrogen is also a key condition.
Necessary retrofits are planned throughout Europe for existing assets to utilize green hydrogen; projects include carbon capture in non-hydrogen plants.

Emphasis on a comprehensive hydrogen value chain from green electricity generation and electrolysis to hydrogen trading and storage, with activities focused in Germany, the Netherlands, and the United Kingdom.

elements.title: Investment in Hydrogen Projects and Infrastructure

data.value: Combined pilot plant to produce up to 290 kg of hydrogen per hour using green energy; investment of approximately €30 million; duration of trial: 3 years

Large-scale hydrogen infrastructure project in partnership with OGE; conversion of natural gas pipelines and construction of new pipelines spanning approximately 1,500 km; plan includes installation of electrolysers with 1 GW capacity and connection of 2 GW hydrogen-capable gas-fired power stations; total budget set at €3.5 billion

Waste-to-hydrogen plant at the Chemelot industrial park in the Netherlands; supports circular economy by converting regional waste into hydrogen; project received a €108 million grant from the EU Innovation Fund; intended for hydrogen production using organic and plastic waste

elements.title: RWE Offshore Wind Projects, Joint Ventures and Completed Wind Farms

data.value: RWE secured rights to lease two offshore sites: New York Bight for US$1.1 billion (approx. 3 GW capacity) in February in partnership with National Grid Ventures, and a site off northern California near Humboldt Bay for US$158 million (potentially 1.6 GW, requiring floating foundations). Commissioning is expected by the end of this decade and mid-2030s, respectively, subject to project progress and approvals.

RWE won a tender for the Hollandse Kust West VII site for an offshore wind farm exceeding 760 MW capacity with all turbines expected online by early 2028. The project is designed to integrate e-boilers, battery storage systems, and/or electrolysers, without receiving state support.

A joint venture with Northland Power was launched for wind power projects north of the island of Juist in Germany, creating over 1.3 GW of capacity. RWE holds a 51% stake, with a subsequent project (225 MW) involving a 49% share for Northland Power.

Projects commissioned include: El Algodon Alto in Texas (200 MW, approx. €280 million investment), Triton Knoll offshore wind farm off eastern England (857 MW, investment of £2.4 billion with RWE holding 59%), and the Swedish onshore wind farm Nysäter (474 MW, €575 million investment).

elements.title: Depreciation and Accounting Policy for Property, Plant & Equipment

data.value: Property, plant and equipment is stated at depreciated cost with capitalised borrowing costs for qualified assets.
Generally depreciated on a straight-line basis, with annual review of methods and useful lives.

Table titled 'Buildings' presents useful life ranges for asset categories (e.g., Thermal power plants: 6-40 years; Wind and solar assets: Up to 25 years; Gas and water storage: 10-60 years; Mining facilities: 3-25 years; etc.).
Measured at cost (present value of lease instalments adjusted for various factors) and depreciated using the straight-line method over the lease term.
Costs for decommissioning, plant restoration, and impairment treatment are also discussed along with the treatment of investments using the equity method.

elements.title: RWE on the capital market 2022

data.value: The war in Ukraine, inflation, and rising interest rates caused a significant decline in market sentiment, with the DAX falling by 12%.
The RWE stock performed significantly better than the DAX and STOXX Europe 600 Utilities, achieving a 19% return including dividend.
RWE made substantial progress in financing and implementing its growth strategy, particularly in expanding the renewables portfolio.
Increased green bond volume by €3 billion to almost €5 billion, intended for renewable expansion.
The conflict in Ukraine caused a spike in commodity prices due to reduced fuel imports from Russia.
Included a dividend payment of €0.90 paid in May.
Curtailed coal and gas supplies from Russia and additional levies on electricity revenues affected earnings.

elements.title: Financial Performance and Forecast Analysis

data.value: EBITDA, EBIT and adjusted net income are used to manage the business, with special items removed to improve explanatory power.
Forecast figures are compared to budget figures; significant deviations trigger analysis, countermeasures, and updated notifications to the capital market.
The internal rate of return (IRR) is calculated using the weighted average cost of capital (WACC) plus project-specific risk premiums, determining minimum acceptable returns.
Free cash flow is derived by deducting capital expenditure from operating cash flows and adding proceeds from divestments and asset disposals.
The leverage factor, defined as net debt to adjusted EBITDA, is managed to maintain financial flexibility with target limits.

elements.title: Adjusted Financial Result Methodology and Non-operating Result Presentation

data.value: RWE Annual Report 2022 – Combined review of operations with commentary on financial result adjustments.

As of fiscal 2022, the methodology for presenting the financial result was adjusted. Previously, the indicator included unadjusted special items affecting comparability. Now, items such as discount rate adjustments for nuclear or mining provisions and temporary gains/losses from valuing currency derivatives used for hedging are excluded from the core financial result and reported under non-operating results as 'Adjustments to the financial result'.
Prior-year figures are presented using the new methodology to allow comparison over time.
The report contains forward-looking statements regarding future developments, economic and political trends, with appropriate risk disclosures.

elements.title: Combined review of operations & KPI definitions

data.value: RWE has had a tax compliance management system based on German audit standards since 2019, monitored internally and through quarterly reviews of tax declarations, payments, and risks.
Reporting is based on three KPIs: revenue, capital expenditure (CapEx), and operating expenditure (OpEx) using EU Taxonomy definitions.
Proportion of net revenues from goods or services associated with taxonomy-aligned business activities relative to total consolidated revenues.

Proportion of additions to property, plant and equipment and intangible assets before depreciation, amortisation, and re-evaluations associated with taxonomy-aligned activities relative to total CapEx.

Proportion of direct, non-capitalised costs (including R&D, building refurbishment, short-term leasing, maintenance and repair, and other direct asset maintenance costs) associated with taxonomy-aligned activities relative to total OpEx.
Daily maintenance expenditures primarily relate to wind and solar farms and conventional power plants, including service cost, material, personnel, and other operating expenses.

Business activities were directly assigned or allocated via internal procedures to taxonomy-aligned, taxonomy-eligible but non-aligned, and non-eligible activities based on the source of revenues, CapEx, and OpEx.

elements.title: Consolidated Financial Statements – Foreign Currency Translation and Hyperinflation Effects

data.value: Elimination of intra-group profits and losses, derecognition of associated goodwill on deconsolidation, and analogous treatment for investments accounted for using the equity method.

Non-monetary items measured at initial recognition exchange rate; monetary items converted at balance-sheet date rates. Exchange rate gains and losses are recognized in the income statement, while differences for companies outside the Eurozone are recorded in other comprehensive income.

A table is provided with exchange rates against the Euro for various currencies (USD, GBP, Czech koruna, Polish zloty, Danish crown, Swedish crown, and Norwegian crown) for 2021 and 2022, including average and year-end rates.

Türkiye is classified as a hyperinflationary economy (since 30 June 2022) according to IAS 29. The financial statements reflect a retrospective adjustment of €20 million in equity and a €13 million loss from monetary items, impacting depreciation, amortisation, and impairment losses.
IAS 29 is applied for the Turkish subsidiary and IAS 21 is referenced for foreign currency translations.

elements.title: Notes on Balance Sheet Accounting and Valuation

data.value: Comprise financial receivables, trade accounts receivable, and other receivables. They are generally stated at amortised cost minus a risk provision for expected losses. Loans are reported at amortised cost, with common market interest rate loans shown at nominal value and non- or low-interest loans disclosed at present value.

Result from temporary differences between IFRS carrying amounts and tax bases, including tax reduction claims from loss carryforwards. Deferred tax assets are capitalised when the future economic advantage is sufficiently certain. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are netted for each company or tax group.

Include goods held for sale, work in progress, and raw materials. Inventories not acquired for short-term resale are carried at the lower of cost or net realisable value, with production costs incorporating directly allocable costs, materials, overheads, and production-related depreciation. Inventories for short-term resale are recognised at fair value less costs to sell, with changes affecting income.

Current marketable securities, mainly fixed-interest securities with maturities between three months and one year, are measured partly at fair value (through profit or loss or other comprehensive income) and partly at amortised cost. Transaction costs are included in initial measurement, and unrealised gains/losses are recognised according to their measurement categories.
CO2 emission allowances and renewable energy certificates are accounted for as intangible assets, reported at cost under other assets and not subject to amortisation.

Nuclear fuel assemblies are stated at amortised cost with depreciation determined by usage, capacity, and reactor useful life. Fair value adjustments for inventory held for resale are recognised in income.

elements.title: Consolidated Financial Statements Notes

data.value: Gains and losses on the revaluation of net defined benefit liability or asset are fully recognised in the fiscal year in which they occur, reported outside profit or loss as a component of other comprehensive income, and immediately assigned to retained earnings.
For defined contribution plans, the enterprise’s obligation is limited to its contributions, which are reported under staff costs.

Waste management provisions in the nuclear energy sector are based on obligations under public law (e.g. German Atomic Energy Act) and operating license restrictions, measured using estimates defined in contracts and expert information.

Provisions are recognised for obligations covering land recultivation, resettlement, relocation and remediation of mining damage, in line with public law (German Federal Mining Act) and based largely on external expert opinions.

A provision is recognised to cover the obligation to submit CO2 emission allowances and renewable energy certificates; measured primarily at the secured forward price, or at market price if forward purchase isn’t available.

Financial liabilities, trade accounts payable, income tax liabilities and derivatives are initially stated at fair value and carried at amortised cost. Lease liabilities are measured at the present value of future lease payments, divided into financing costs and principal repayment.

Government grants for asset acquisition are recorded as deferrals under other liabilities and reversed over the economic life of the asset, while grants related to income are offset against their corresponding expenses.
Derivatives are recognised as assets or liabilities and measured at fair value, with changes recognised in income unless they are used for hedge accounting purposes.

elements.title: Hedge Accounting and Tax Equity Financing Disclosure

data.value: The document details the recognition of various hedging instruments including fair value hedges and cash flow hedges. It explains that hedges of unrecognised firm commitments are recorded as fair value hedges, with changes in fair value affecting either the income statement or other comprehensive income depending on the hedge type. The discussion also covers net investment hedges used to mitigate currency risk from foreign operations.

Unrealised gains and losses on cash flow hedges are initially recorded in other comprehensive income and then transferred to the income statement when the hedged transaction affects income. Ineffective portions of hedges are recognized immediately in the income statement.

The text explains the concept of tax equity financing for renewable energy projects, where tax equity investors contribute capital recorded under financial liabilities. Repayment is structured via allocation of tax benefits with additional cash flows.

Hedging relationships must be well documented and satisfy criteria regarding economic relationship, credit risk, and hedge ratio. Only the effective portion of the hedge is recognized under the rules described.

elements.title: Management Estimates and Accounting Judgements in Consolidated Financial Statements

data.value: Income from tax items is recognized under other operating income using a straight-line method over the anticipated duration of the tax equity contracts, capped at the likely generated income.

Judgements are required in applying accounting policies regarding the treatment of certain contracts (derivatives vs. own-use), classification of financial assets based on contractual cash flows and business model, and determining if assets held for sale can be sold in their current condition.
Preparation under IFRS requires assumptions and accounting estimates that affect asset and liability values, income, expenses, and the disclosure of contingent liabilities.
Determined based on yields on high-quality, fixed-rate corporate bonds in accordance with maturities and due dates as of the balance-sheet date.
Goodwill and non-current assets are periodically tested for impairment using future-based assumptions subject to regular adjustments.

elements.title: Sensitivity analysis of pension provisions

data.value: The table presents a sensitivity analysis of pension provisions, showing how changes in key actuarial assumptions affect the present value of defined benefit obligations for both domestic and foreign operations for December 2022 compared to December 2021.
Discount rate (±50bp), salary growth (±50bp), pension increase rate (±50bp), and one-year increase in life expectancy.

Larger sensitivity effects are noted in the domestic obligations; discount rate changes cause variations ranging from -715 to +813 million euros in 2021. The table details both positive and negative impacts under different scenarios for domestic and foreign categories.
Funded pension plans: €462 million (2022) compared to €1,367 million (2021); Unfunded pension plans: €438 million (2022) compared to €567 million (2021).

The sensitivity analyses are based on changing one assumption at a time while keeping others constant. The methods for calculating these sensitivities and the pension provisions are consistent, and the effects of market interest rate changes are partially offset by the negative correlation between plan assets and fixed-income security yields.

elements.title: Responsibility Statements and Audit Scope in RWE Annual Report 2022

data.value: The executive directors are responsible for the 'other information' which includes the non‐audited non‐financial group statement (to comply with §§ 315b to 315c HGB), the group corporate governance statement, and remaining parts of the annual report (excluding the audited consolidated financial statements, the audited group management report, and the auditor’s report). The audit opinions on the consolidated financial statements and group management report do not extend to this other information.

During the audit, the auditors review the other information to determine if it is materially inconsistent with the consolidated financial statements, the audited group management report disclosures, or other audit evidence. They are required to report if a material misstatement is found, though in this case they have nothing to report.

data.key: Responsibilities of Executive Directors and Supervisory Board
data.value: The executive directors are responsible for preparing consolidated financial statements that comply with IFRSs as adopted by the EU and German legal requirements (per § 315e Abs. 1 HGB). They must ensure these statements fairly present the assets, liabilities, financial position, and financial performance of the Group, maintain appropriate internal controls, assess the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern, and prepare a group management report that reflects the opportunities and risks for future development and is consistent with the financial statements.

elements.title: Auditor’s Report and Financial Statement Evaluation

data.value: The supervisory board is responsible for overseeing the Group’s financial reporting process for the preparation of the consolidated financial statements and of the group management report.

Obtain reasonable assurance that the consolidated financial statements are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and that the group management report appropriately reflects the Group’s position and complies with legal requirements.

Identify and assess risks of material misstatement, design and perform responsive audit procedures, and evaluate internal control, accounting policies, estimates, and the use of the going concern basis of accounting.
Evaluate the overall presentation, structure, and content of the consolidated financial statements to ensure they represent a true and fair view of the Group’s financial position and performance.

elements.title: Independent Auditor’s Report & Assurance Statement

data.value: The document provides a combined review of operations and an independent auditor’s report for the consolidated financial statements of the Group, including the management report.
The auditors are responsible for obtaining sufficient and appropriate audit evidence, evaluating the group management report, and formulating audit opinions on the consolidated financial statements.

Audit procedures were performed on the prospective information presented by the executive directors, including evaluation of significant assumptions underlying this information, without expressing a separate audit opinion on them.

The auditors communicated with those charged with governance regarding the planned audit scope, timing, and significant audit findings, including deficiencies in internal control and matters related to independence.

The report includes an assurance opinion in accordance with § 317 Abs. 3a HGB on the electronic rendering (ESEF) of the consolidated financial statements and the group management report, confirming compliance with § 328 Abs. 1 HGB.
The report confirms that the financial statements and management report adhere to German law and regulatory requirements.

elements.title: Capital Structure and Liquidity Overview

data.value: The table 'Cash and cash equivalents' shows that cash and demand deposits increased from €5,824 million as of 31 Dec 2021 to €6,988 million as of 31 Dec 2022, representing about a 20% growth. RWE holds demand deposits exclusively for short-term cash positions, with interest rates at market levels.

The subscribed capital table indicates that the number of shares remained constant at 676,220 thousand and the carrying amount at €1,731 million for both periods, reflecting no change in the capital structure.

According to the resolution passed on 28 April 2021, the Executive Board is authorized (subject to the Supervisory Board) to increase the capital stock by up to €346,224,663.04 (about 20% of current stock) until 27 April 2026. A conditional increase of up to €173,112,330.24 and a mandatory convertible bond of €2,427,600,000 issued on 1 October 2022 to Qatar Holding LLC (convertible into about 9.1% of increased capital) further detail planned adjustments in the company’s capital structure.

elements.title: Risk Assessment and Sustainability Strategy Overview

data.value: The statement addresses non-financial risks that may impact the company and stakeholders. Risks cover environmental, employee, social, and human rights aspects, with an emphasis on potential high-probability, material risks.

The risk matrix evaluates various risks including extreme weather events, climate goals, disruption of ecosystems, fatal occupational accidents, lack of employer appeal, demographic change, negative public perception, and human rights violations in the supply chain. Impact levels are rated on a '+' scale: (+) low risk, (++) medium risk, (+++) high risk.

The document outlines a sustainability strategy with a major focus on renewable energy expansion. It details plans to invest approximately €50 billion in new wind and solar farms, battery storage systems, gas-fired power stations, and electrolysers through 2030, with capital expenditure estimated at around €30 billion after divestments. The acquisition of US-based Con Edison Clean Energy Businesses is highlighted as a key element.
The page integrates risk factor assessment with an overview of RWE's strategic shift towards sustainable and renewable energy, aligning risk management with long-term business transformation.

elements.title: Safety Metrics & Occupational Health and Safety Overview

data.value: The document displays a table of safety metrics for the RWE Group, including Lost Time Injury Frequency (LTIF) and fatal work-related accidents for the years 2021 and 2022. It highlights improvements in LTIF figures—with reductions of 0.4 and 0.5 for the group and for contract workers respectively—and provides details on fatal accidents.

The text explains that all fatal accidents and events that could lead to serious injuries are subjected to systematic investigations via root cause analysis. It also outlines prevention programmes aimed at ensuring responsible occupational health and safety practices.

The document notes that in February 2022, the RWE Group transferred the responsibility for enforcing international minimum standards for coronavirus protective measures to its operating companies, while local risk assessments now guide hygiene, social distancing, and other preventive measures.

The narrative discusses the broader transformation of the company including decommissioning of plants, closure of long-operating sites, and the resulting impacts on employees, suppliers, partners, and local communities. This is framed within the context of a just and socially acceptable transition.

elements.title: Business environment & Regulatory Measures

data.value: Review of regulations and temporary levies affecting power generation operations.

Gas-fired and nuclear power plants classified as sustainable under EU Taxonomy Regulation subject to certain criteria (e.g., CO2 emission limits of 270 g CO2/kWh or 550 kg CO2/kWh annual average over 20 years).
EU Commission signed a delegated act in February 2022 establishing the classification framework; effective from 1 January 2023.

Extraordinary levies on electricity revenues introduced by EU nations and the UK; details include redirection of 90% of revenues above technology-specific price thresholds (e.g., €180/MWh in EU recommendation, Germany and Netherlands specifics provided).

Germany: Levy in force from 1 December 2022 until 30 June 2023 (potential extension) with revenue caps based on technology-specific costs; Netherlands: Similar 90% redirection above set thresholds; UK has enacted similar measures.
Gas-fired power plants remain exempt; hard coal-fired power stations exempt in some cases (Germany) but not uniformly across all jurisdictions.

elements.title: Regulatory Reforms on Energy Production & Renewables Expansion

data.value: Since 1 January 2023, revenue above £75/MWh is taxed at 45% regardless of technology, with gas-fired power plants and renewables (supported via contracts for difference) exempt.

Legislative amendments set new targets: 80% renewable electricity by 2030 (previously 65%), offshore wind capacity to 30 GW by 2030 and 70 GW by 2045, onshore wind and photovoltaic capacities to 115 GW and 215 GW by 2030 with annual build-out rates of 10 GW and 22 GW respectively.
Every state must earmark an average of 2% of its land for onshore wind by 2032 (current allocation is 0.8%).

A two-track system introduced: pre-investigated sites require meeting qualitative and financial criteria, while non-investigated sites involve a bidding process where a zero-subsidy bid can be outbid in the next round.

data.key: Coal Exit in the Rhenish Region
data.value: Coal power generation using lignite is to be stopped by 2030, eight years ahead of original plans; compensation (€2.6 billion under the Coal Phaseout Act of 2020) remains unchanged pending EU Commission approval, with approximately 280 million metric tons of coal remaining unused.
Three modern lignite-fired plants (3.1 GW capacity) are set for decommissioning by 31 March 2030, with a possibility of a standby period until late 2033 if requested by the German government.

For Neurath D (607 MW) and Neurath E (604 MW), decommissioning was deferred from 31 December 2022 to 31 March 2024, with potential extension or conversion into a power plant reserve until 31 March 2025 to support reduced gas usage during the energy crisis.

data.value: IFRS 3 Business Combinations (Reference to the Conceptual Framework 2020), IAS 16 Property, Plant and Equipment (Proceeds before Intended Use 2020), IAS 37 Provisions, Contingent Liabilities and Contingent Assets (Onerous Contracts – Cost of Fulfilling a Contract 2020), Annual Improvements to IFRS Standards 2018-2020

Change in the reporting of amounts from CfD contracts: state subsidies and refunds now reported in cost of materials, with previous year figures adjusted by an increase of €45 million in both revenue and cost of materials
The new accounting regulations do not have any material effects on the RWE Group’s consolidated financial statements

elements.title: Coal Phaseout and Energy Transition Strategy

data.value: Hard coal phased out in the UK and Germany; Dutch stations to cease hard coal use from 2025 and 2030; lignite phaseout in the Rhenish region planned for 2030 with complications.
Comprehensive compensatory measures and statutory adjustment allowances will be provided to affected employees to mitigate social hardship.
Plans to build at least 500 MW of wind and solar capacities in the Rhenish region, including repurposing recultivated land and utilizing existing wind farm sites.

intentions to operate new hydrogen-compatible gas-fired stations, develop an innovation and technology park, and construct a megabattery; ongoing research in power-to-gas technology at the Niederaussem Innovation Centre.
Deviation from the existing coal exit roadmap necessitates significant planning adjustments in response to government policy changes and energy security considerations.

elements.title: Restructuring of Renewables and Group Organizational Structure

data.value: RWE restructured its renewables activities. RWE Renewables will no longer be solely responsible for renewables operations; these have been redistributed across three organizational units.
RWE Renewables Americas was renamed RWE Clean Energy following the acquisition of Con Edison Clean Energy Businesses on 1 March 2023.

The RWE Group is divided into five segments: Offshore Wind, Onshore Wind/Solar, Hydro/Biomass/Gas, Supply & Trading, and Coal/Nuclear. The first four represent the core business focused on the energy transition, while the fifth is non-core with a declining role due to phaseout roadmaps.
Despite the restructuring, the reporting structure remains unchanged, with economic responsibilities for each segment assigned to individual RWE AG subsidiaries.

elements.title: ESG and Strategic Transformation Initiatives

data.value: RWE aims to almost double generation capacity in its green core business through new wind and solar farms, battery storage systems, gas-fired power plants, and electrolysers.
Accelerated exit from coal-fired (lignite) generation with an agreement to cease production by 2030, eight years ahead of schedule.
The strategy supports alignment with the 1.5-degree goal of the Paris Climate Conference.
Implementation of the strategy has progressed despite challenges such as the war in Ukraine and the resulting energy crisis.

elements.title: Sustainability and Energy Transition Strategy

data.value: RWE aims to be carbon neutral by 2040, with upstream and downstream value chain included.
Shifting from oil, coal, and gas to renewable sources such as wind power, photovoltaics, battery storage, and hydrogen economy to reduce emissions across sectors.
Investing in the hydrogen economy as a solution for sectors where direct electrification is not feasible, such as steel and fertilizer production.
Temporarily increasing coal-fired power and continuing operations of certain lignite and nuclear units to ensure security of supply amid external challenges like the war in Ukraine.
Sustainability is central to RWE's corporate culture, with detailed ESG goals and an integrated strategy for environmental, social, and governance considerations.

elements.title: Business Environment and Regulatory Update

data.value: Russia’s war against Ukraine disrupted European energy markets, leading to extreme highs in electricity and gas trading and prompting policy responses.
The EU and UK introduced new energy policies and accelerated renewable energy expansion to reduce dependence on Russian commodity imports.
US Inflation Reduction Act supports investments in green tech, while the EU recovery package is bolstered by an additional €20 billion raised via emission allowances.
REPowerEU package envisions a 45% share of renewable primary energy by 2030, boosting wind capacity to 510 GW and solar capacity to nearly 600 GW, along with advancing the hydrogen economy.
The EU agreed to reform its ETS with stricter targets (62% greenhouse gas reduction by 2030 vs 2005 levels), implementing annual certificate reductions starting in 2024.

elements.title: Non-Financial Group Statement & Sustainability Initiatives

data.value: We Grow – sustainable investments and innovation; We Act – climate change, biodiversity, circular economy; We Care – social responsibility, diversity, compliance, occupational health and safety.

Integrated approach with responsibilities distributed among the Executive Board, Supervisory Board, Strategy & Sustainability Department, Legal, Compliance & Insurance Department, and Chief HR Officer.
Reporting includes quarterly updates by the Strategy & Sustainability Department and periodic online questionnaires in 2021 and 2022 involving both external stakeholders and employees.
The Executive Board is responsible for setting and achieving sustainability objectives with sustainability targets directly influencing their short-term and long-term remuneration.
Topics were identified through stakeholder dialogues, online surveys, and an analysis of relevant sustainability rankings and standards.

elements.title: Non-financial Statement Material Topics

data.value: To our investors: Combined review of operations Non-financial Group statement. Responsibility statement: the Non-financial Statement focuses on strategic topics relevant to RWE, incorporating new topics such as those tied to the sustainability components of the Executive Board's remuneration.
This table outlines RWE's sustainability strategy framework, organized into three main sections: Environment, Social, and Governance (ESG).

Environment: Climate change – 'Clear pledge to protect the climate' (Environmental matters); Environment: Innovation – 'Technologies driving sustainable development' (Environmental matters); Environment: Biodiversity and recultivation – 'Growth in harmony with biodiversity' (Environmental matters); Environment: Circular economy – 'Driving the circular economy' (Environmental matters); Social: Diversity, equity and inclusion – 'Promoting diversity and inclusion within the company' (Employee matters); Social: Occupational health and safety – 'Staying safe and healthy at RWE' (Employee matters); Social: Social responsibility – 'Driving change together and justly' (Social matters); Governance: Compliance and ethical behaviour Sustainable investments – 'Integrity and legal compliance are pillars of our action, EU Taxonomy' (Anti-corruption and combatting bribery; Respect for human rights).

The report details major strategic topics such as climate change, decarbonising electricity production, shifting from conventional to renewable energy, reducing Scope 1, 2 and 3 emissions and the goal to be carbon neutral by 2040. It also discusses capital expenditure on renewable energy and the phasing out of fossil-fuel assets.
Environmental management, including topics like climate change and decarbonisation, is directly linked to the variable remuneration of the Executive Board.

elements.title: ESG Initiatives and Emissions Performance

data.value: Reduce Scope 1 and 2 GHG emissions per unit of electricity by 27% and Scope 3 emissions by 15% relative to 2019.
Achieve a 50% drop in Scope 1 and 2 emissions per unit and a 30% reduction in Scope 3 emissions, as confirmed by the Science Based Targets initiative.
Average carbon intensity of the power plant fleet (metric tons CO2 per megawatt of installed capacity per full-load hour) used in long-term executive remuneration.
83.0 million metric tons in 2022 vs 80.9 million metric tons in 2021, change of +21 units.
Scope 1 increased to 89.6 million mt CO2e (up 2.7), Scope 2 increased slightly to 2.8 (up 0.1), Scope 3 decreased to 22.1 (down 0.6); additional breakdown provided for various categories.
Increased emissions in lignite-fired power plants due to higher capacity utilisation amid gas shortages; changes in calculation methodology impacted reported figures.

elements.title: RWE Group Carbon Intensity Metrics

data.value: Carbon intensity (Scope 1 and 2) mt CO2e per MWh RWE Group – 2021: 0.50, 2022: 0.57, change: +0.07

The table presents carbon intensity metrics for RWE Group across 2021 and 2022. Scope 1 and 2 emissions intensity increased, while the average power plant carbon intensity improved, indicating better efficiency in plant operations.

In early October 2022, RWE agreed with the German government and the state of North Rhine-Westphalia to phase out lignite electricity production by 2030, advancing the timeline by eight years. This, along with initiatives such as switching to climate-friendly electricity at office sites, reviewing emissions in the supply chain, and partnering with steel producer ArcelorMittal on green energy projects, forms part of RWE's broader sustainability strategy.

elements.title: Environmental Management and Biodiversity Initiatives

data.value: Adopts ISO 14001:2015 standards; groupwide environmental policy emphasizing biodiversity protection and sustainable operations.
Established in 2022 to supplement existing 2015 rules, ensuring minimal impact on ecosystems and promoting restoration during land recultivation.
Achieved 100% coverage in 2021 and exceeded 100% in 2022, serving as a key performance indicator.
No severe incidents reported; table data uses notations ([e) and fe)) with an indicated negative trend.
Environmental matters are reported through integrated compliance systems with involvement of environmental officers and central coordinators.

elements.title: ESG and Circular Economy Initiatives

data.value: Launched a pilot project at onshore wind farms near Bedburg to enhance species variety on and around the site.
Participated in the Dutch Black Blade study to assess whether black rotor blades increase visibility for birds and reduce collisions.
Implemented initiatives to boost circular economy practices by increasing circular quotas, reducing dependency on primary materials, and promoting resource efficiency.
Set a goal to achieve a recycling rate of over 90% by 2030, with further ambitions of maximizing circular compatibility by 2050.
Submitted an innovative ecological concept in bids, contributing to new ideas in biodiversity and resource-friendly economy initiatives.

elements.title: Diversity, Inclusion and Gender Diversity Initiatives

data.value: RWE emphasizes diversity, inclusion, and antidiscrimination as part of its ESG initiatives. The report highlights policies such as the RWE Antidiscrimination Policy, Diversity & Inclusion Week, and the establishment of various networks (Women’s Network, LGBT*IQ & Friends Network, Diversity Ambassadors, etc.) to foster an inclusive corporate culture.

RWE aims to have women in leadership positions, requiring all leadership and management role shortlists to include at least one woman. In the core business, the target is to reach 30% female representation in managerial roles, although in 2022 the percentage was 20.8%.
At the close of 2022, the 20-member Supervisory Board included seven women (with four as employer representatives) and the Executive Board had a 33.3% female composition.
For RWE Group (core business)*, the percentage increased from 19.0% in 2021 to 20.8% in 2022, showing an improvement with a noted change of 18 (as per table summary).
The report also addresses statutory mandates on gender diversity and the 5% quota for severely disabled people in leadership positions in Germany.

elements.title: Occupational Health and Safety (H&S) and Employee Wellbeing Initiatives

data.value: RWE’s non-financial statement emphasizes the importance of occupational health and safety, highlighting that all accidents are avoidable. The company prioritizes employee health, safety, and wellbeing across diverse workplaces.

The Chief Human Resources Officer and Labour Director, supported by the Health and Safety Unit of RWE Power AG, is responsible for coordinating and assessing occupational H&S across the Group. Each Group company must designate an executive or board member for H&S compliance.

The Group has established occupational safety management systems, following a plan-do-check-act cycle. Guidelines are systematically monitored and improved, with recommendations for external certifications (e.g., ISO 45001).

A key performance indicator is the Lost Time Incident Frequency (LTIF), with a target of 1.9 incidents per 1 million work hours. The LTIF decreased from 1.5 in 2022 for the Group and 1.1 for RWE personnel, despite a prior exceedance in 2021.

The report notes a fatal accident involving a contract worker in November 2022 while cleaning a coaling system at a power plant, emphasizing the ongoing commitment to zero fatal work-related accidents.
H&S measures and services are designed to meet the needs of employees in various settings, including offices, wind farms, opencast mines, and power stations.

elements.title: Compliance and Ethics Approach

data.value: Established CMS for the RWE Group, regularly reviewed in accordance with IDW 980 standards, with overall oversight by the Chief Compliance Officer.
Mandatory annual compliance training (web-based and in-person) for all employees including the Executive Board to reinforce ethical behavior and anti-corruption measures.
A web-based, confidential, and anonymous reporting system is available for reporting breaches of the Code of Conduct and potential compliance violations.
Compliance officers in Group companies report to the Chief Compliance Officer, who in turn keeps the Executive Board and Supervisory Board’s Audit Committee informed.
Strict zero tolerance for corruption, bribery, and other compliance infractions, supported by systematic risk assessments and preventive measures.

elements.title: Feedback rate of the executives' compliance survey

data.value: The table shows that the executives' compliance survey achieved a 100% feedback rate in both 2022 and 2021, reflecting full participation and strong compliance culture at RWE Group.

elements.title: Compliance, Risk Management and Due Diligence Initiatives

data.value: All managers report annually on Code of Conduct adherence, achieving 100% feedback rate.

data.key: Due Diligence for Human Rights and Environment
data.value: A risk management system was introduced to detect and minimise human rights and environmental risks in line with the upcoming German Supply Chain Due Diligence Act.
Policy statement published by the Executive Board and a Human Rights Officer designated; future assignment to the Head of Strategy & Sustainability.

These initiatives underscore RWE Group’s commitment to enforcing a robust compliance culture, integrating sustainability and risk management practices, and ensuring full due diligence in supplier relationships and broader ESG concerns.

elements.title: ESG and Risk Management Disclosures

data.value: Performed a risk analysis in 2022 to identify human rights and environmental risks in business operations and among direct suppliers. No substantial risks were discovered, although some potential supplier-related risks are under further review.
High priority is given to monitoring supply chains of raw materials needed for wind and solar farm projects as well as battery storage systems, especially in relation to human rights conditions.

For the first time, the company has reported taxonomy-aligned activities under the EU Taxonomy framework, focusing on sustainable investments, climate change mitigation, and renewable energy production and storage, as part of the European Green Deal objectives.

elements.title: EU Taxonomy Compliance and Sustainability Analysis

data.value: The document outlines the review of business activities with respect to EU Taxonomy, assessing eligibility and alignment for activities such as electricity generation from renewables and natural gas, and explains the criteria and process for taxonomy alignment.

Activities like electricity generation from natural gas (eligible but not aligned), and renewables (wind, photovoltaics, hydropower) which are taxonomy-aligned. Also includes electricity storage and hydrogen production.

Activities including bioenergy (not currently aligned due to exclusive use criteria), certain offshore wind farms pending further measures, and electricity generation from coal and nuclear energy which are not taxonomy-eligible.

A multi-stage process is described including clustering of asset portfolios by business activity and region, and assessment against technical screening criteria for major contribution to climate change mitigation, as well as evaluation of potential harm to other environmental goals.
References are made to the EU Taxonomy Regulation and supplementary delegated legal acts, particularly regarding gas and nuclear activities.

elements.title: Sustainability, Climate Risk Assessment and ESG Initiatives

data.value: A systematic, group-level approach to climate change adaptation was carried out, including the first cross-portfolio climate risk assessment for taxonomy-aligned business activities. The assessment used global climate models to evaluate climate projections for the lifetimes of new assets.

Identified technology-specific climate hazards such as changes in wind, sunshine, precipitation, and drought duration. Adaptation solutions (e.g., flood protection for run-of-river power stations, retaining basins for water-cooled plants) were implemented.

The report addresses multiple sustainability objectives linked to EU taxonomy goals: goal 2 (climate adaptation), goal 3 (sustainable use and protection of water and marine resources), goal 4 (transition to a circular economy), goal 5 (pollution prevention and control), and goal 6 (protection and restoration of biodiversity and ecosystems).

Compliance is demonstrated through permit applications, environmental impact assessments, and adherence to minimum safeguards on human rights, anti-corruption, labor standards, and other key areas as defined by EU and international standards.
